Deficiency Narrative: A child's file reviewed did not have an admission assessment for the child's re-admission; the child was previously admitted to the operation in Aug. 2024 and re-admitted on Jan. 4, 2025.
A video recording was provided of a staff member using inappropriate language towards a child in care.
Correction Narrative: During individual interviews staff and children interviewed denied any abusive or profane language at the operation.

Deficiency Narrative: A video recording indicates that a staff member provoked a child by using verbal commands and hand gestures in a manner that challenged the child to fight.
Correction Narrative: During individual interviews staff and children interviewed denied any knowledge of staff provoking a child to engage in a physical altercation.

Deficiency Narrative: The two service plans obtained for the investigation were not signed by the youth nor was their refusal to sign documented.
Correction Narrative:
The following corrective action was provided by the operation via email: 
The administrator reviewed standard 748.1349(b)(2) concerning this incident. To prevent future occurrences, the administrator will implement quality assurance checks to verify that all Service Plans are signed by the youth. In cases where the child refuses to sign, the refusal will be formally documented in accordance with agency policy and minimum standards.

Deficiency Narrative: The childs medication reviewed did not indicate the accurate count of the remaining pills.
Correction Narrative:
Two children's medications were reviewed and were observed to include the accurate daily count of each prescribed medication. 

A face-to-face interview was conducted with staff. She stated that the new form works better for the children who have to take medication for AM and Midday which allows them to use the same sheet and accurately track the count medication instead of using separate sheets for the same medication that is administered multiple times a day.

Deficiency Narrative: A video recording indicated a staff member cursing at a child in care.
Correction Narrative:
A corrective action plan was submitted via email by the Administrator stating that the staff member involved was immediately terminated, as ADIEE maintains a zero-tolerance policy for such behavior. To prevent future occurrences, the administrator will continue providing staff training to reinforce compliance with licensing standards and ensure the health, safety, and well-being of all children in care. ADIEE remains committed to maintaining a safe and supportive environment through consistent supervision and adequate care.

Interviews were conducted with children in care during inspection #4071230. The children interviewed denied the use of profane language.

Deficiency Narrative: A video recording indicated a staff member yelling at a child in care.
Correction Narrative:
A corrective action plan was submitted via email by the Administrator stating that the staff member involved was immediately terminated, as ADIEE maintains a zero-tolerance policy for such behavior. To prevent future occurrences, the administrator will continue providing staff training to reinforce compliance with licensing standards and ensure the health, safety, and well-being of all children in care. ADIEE remains committed to maintaining a safe and supportive environment through consistent supervision and adequate care.

Interviews were conducted with children in care during inspection #4071230. The children interviewed staff yell at them.

Deficiency Narrative: Incident report received regarding AWOL was missing departure and return times.
Correction Narrative: The administrator will ensure incident reports regarding AWOL will have departure and return times.

Deficiency Narrative: Discharge plan provided is missing several details including circumstances of discharge.
Correction Narrative: The Discharge form has been updated and complies with minimum standards.

Deficiency Narrative: AWOL log provided was for 1 child. Missing age, gender, and date of admission.
Correction Narrative: The administrator reviewed standard 748.453(a)1 and will ensure that all minimum standards are followed by verifying that all staff review and complete all documents in their entirety.

Deficiency Narrative: A service plan for a child in care identified as receiving treatment services did not contain two professionals on the service planning team.
Correction Narrative: The following corrective action plan was provided by the operation indicating:  MOVING FORWARD WE WILL ALWAYS PLAN AND MAKE SURE THAT THERE ARE TWO PROFESSIONAL SIGNATURES ON THE SERVICE PLAN.

Deficiency Narrative:
During a review conducted on March 31, 2025, it was determined that: 

(1)    your operations administrator failed to ensure compliance with the current HM Plan(s); and 

(2)    12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.

As you know, the heightened monitoring plans for your operation included a specific planned end date at the 12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring.  As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plans, your operation is now unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring.  Furthermore, your operations planned end date must now be revised, and the period of heightened monitoring must be extended again. 

Further details of the failure of your operations administrator to ensure compliance include the following: 
- Operation was unable to meet compliance with Medium-High or High weighted licensing citations, including having an open investigation(s). 

Finding: 748.535(2)  The licensed administrator must ensure the operation complies with current heightened monitoring plans.
Correction Narrative: An HM extension was approved effective 4/1/2025.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your CPA/GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 10/01/2025.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation did not report two children in care's unauthorized absences to their CVS workers within the required time frame by minimum standards.
Correction Narrative: Email received from the operation: "THE CORRECTIONS THAT WE MAKE MOVING FORWARD WILL BE TO CALL, TEXT AND/ OR EMAIL THE CASEWORKER THE SAME TIME WE CALL INTAKE. WE HAD A MEETING AND DISCUSSED THIS PROCESS WITH ALL STAFF."

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation, it was learned that the operation failed to notify the conservator of the child timely. Notification was not made about the incident until the following day.
Correction Narrative: Director sent email stating they will email and call the case worker whether the youth is detained or arrested. This was discussed with all staff.

Deficiency Narrative: There was no documentation indicating that a debriefing took place with all of the required components according to the minimum standards.
Correction Narrative: Email received from the operation with a new form for the Runaway Report and Debriefing Report. Form meets all components required.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation reports they were unaware staff was required to complete an annual suicide prevention training.
Correction Narrative:
Training certificates for staff members were sent and reviewed.

 Email received from the operation: "Our corrective action moving forward is to make sure that all direct care staff will be trained annually on suicide prevention."

Deficiency Narrative: During a review of incident reports and runaway incident reports, on multiple records the documentation was incomplete.
Correction Narrative: This standard was evaluated and found to be compliant.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation failed to employ a licensed administrator within the 120-day allotted timeframe.
Correction Narrative: The operation hired an administrator that was present during Inspection #4017860 on 09/03/2024.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation failed to employ a licensed administrator within the 90-day allotted timeframe.
The operation was not able the triggered reviews and stated they are not required to complete triggered reviews.
Correction Narrative:
Received the following email from the operation: 
CORRECTIVE ACTION
On 08/12/24 RCCL came out to conduct an investigation : It is alleged that children in care being inappropriately supervised.
Standard # 748.463(e) Unauthorized Absence Evaluation -results of each overall operation evaluation for unauthorized absences must be available to CCR for review and reproduction upon request.
Corrective Action: Adiee has created an unauthorized absence log that covers: the child name; time he left; time he returned; and the facility will be using form 3300 to document the trigger review and post action upon the residents return. All unauthorized absences will be documented on each child that is out of area.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation failed to employ a licensed administrator within the 60-day allotted timeframe.
There was an indication that containment was required in the serious incident report, but the operation did not complete a restraint report.
Correction Narrative: I, RCCL Inspector Michonne Chandler received an email from the operation with a corrective action plan from the operation's case manager stating the following. A training was conducted on documenting serious incident reporting and the form that the facility uses to document the EBI's on was covered in its entirety. Training was conducted on 6/19/2024. A copy of this form is attached to this corrective plan. This form will be attached in the Document Library.

Deficiency Narrative: The caregiver did not have any type of discussion after the incident with the child.
Correction Narrative: I, RCCL Inspector Michonne Chandler received an email from the operation with a corrective action plan from the operation's case manager stating the following. A training was conducted on documenting serious incident reporting and the form that the facility uses to document the EBI's on was covered in its entirety. Training was conducted on 6/19/2024. A copy of this form is attached to this corrective plan. This form will be attached in the Document Library.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation staff confirmed they do not conduct triggered reviews following 3 unauthorized absences within a 60-day timeframe.
Correction Narrative:
CORRECTIVE ACTION
Licensing officials recently investigated at our facility regarding Serious Incident. After their thorough examination, it was determined that Adiee Emergency Shelter failed to meet the minimum standard 748.303(a)(10)(A) For Serious Incident Reporting; Minimum Standard: 748,457(a): 748.455(a) Specifically, it was found that caregivers did not report the incident in a timely manner; there was no trigger review conducted after the third occurrence; and the child was not debriefing upon his return.
To rectify these deficiencies and ensure the safety and well-being of all children, Adiee Emergency Shelter will undertake the following corrective actions.
1. Review and Update Policies: We will carefully evaluate our current policies concerning Serious Incident Reporting; Trigger Reviews, and debriefing the children upon their return. We will ensure that these policies align with best practices, local laws, and regulations. If necessary, we will make updates to clearly emphasize the importance of reporting in a timely manner; trigger review after the third occurrence; and debriefing the children upon there return.
2. Training and Education: Comprehensive training will be provided to all staff members involved in the reporting of serious incidents; trigger reviews; and debriefing the children upon their return. This training will cover important topics such as how, when, where and who you report the serious incident report. The time that you are supposed to report the unauthorized absence, who you call to report the unauthorized absence and how to write the reported information correctly.
3. Clear Guidelines: We will develop clear guidelines and protocols for staff to follow when reporting a serious incident; trigger reviews, and unauthorized absence. These guidelines will strongly encourage the importance of reporting serious incident report; trigger reviews; and unauthorized absences. We will ensure that these guidelines are easily accessible, well-communicated, and regularly reviewed with all staff members.
4. Continuous Supervision: We will implement a system of continuous supervision, where staff members will actively monitor and assess the completion of all paperwork required for the task at hand. This proactive approach will allow the facility to ensure that all documentation is being reviewed.
5. Reporting and Documentation: Establish a clear procedure for reporting and documenting instances where Serious Incident reporting: Trigger reviews, and unauthorized absence occur. We will do everything in our power to ensure that all children receive the utmost care and protection they deserve.

Deficiency Narrative: During the inspection, it was found that there is no incident report regarding the unauthorized absence that took place on March 14, 2024
Correction Narrative:
Received the following email from the operation:

CORRECTIVE ACTION
On March 14,2024 RCCL came to do an unannounced visit and the following deficiency was cited Standard: 748.311: Serious Incident Documentation -Documented in written report.
Corrective Action-  Adiee Shelter will ensure that all unauthorized absence are documented on a Serious Incident report. The facility also has in place a unauthorized absence log, so that each unauthorized absence is documented in the log so each occurrence is documented. The information on the log contain: the name of the child; the date of the occurrence; what time the child left; what time the child returned; who was contacted about the child absence; the intake individual ID #; the name of the intake person; police officer ID#; the police officer name; and the Case #. This process has been initiated immediately. The Executive Director will ensure that this process is implemented.

standard 748.453(a)(2) Unauthorized Absence Annual Summary Log
Corrective Action: Administrator will ensure that all staff will be trained on recording Unauthorized Absences and documentation to the logbook by June 1, 2024
  

Thank you,
[Redacted] / Owner"
Additionally, a sign in sheet was provided for the training.

Deficiency Narrative: The medication logs for two children could not be provided.
Correction Narrative:
I received an email from the operation stating "all residents being discharged will have their discharge and medication paperwork scanned upon discharge and filed. 

5/7/24 - Received a message requesting more information for compliance to be met. I emailed the operation and asked if they could provide additional information on how they plan to prevent medication logs from going missing.

Deficiency Narrative: During the review of the incident report, it was noted that there was no report for March 12, 2024.
Correction Narrative:
Response received from the operation:
Corrective Action: Administrator will ensure that all staff will be trained on recording Unauthorized Absences and documentation to the logbook by June 1, 2024.

Deficiency Narrative: During the review of the summary log it was noted that the incident that occurred on 03/14/24 involving a child jumping from the second floor window and leaving unbeknownst staff was not recorded on the log.
Correction Narrative:
Response received from the operation:
Corrective Action: Administrator will ensure that all staff will be trained on recording Unauthorized Absences and documentation to the logbook by June 1, 2024.

Deficiency Narrative: During the course of the inspection, it was determined that the adminstrator does not maintain full time hours.
Correction Narrative:
On 03/28/2024, I received the following email from the operation:
 
"On March 1,2024 RCCL came to do an unannounced visit and the following deficiency was cited Standard: 748.151(1) Operational responsibilities- Designate a qualified full-time child-care administrator.
Corrective Action-  Adiee Shelter will actively start searching for a License Childcare Administrator. [The administrator's] last day will be April 11,2024. In the interim of finding an Administrator [the owner] with the assistance of the Case Manager will oversee the day - today operation of the business of Adiee Shelter. If there are any question, please contact [the owner]."

During an inspection on 04/01/2024, the operation stated that they are developing [a co-owner], and preparing him to test for his LCCA License, but continuing the search online via a job-seeking website, depending on how long the process takes.

No concerns.

Deficiency Narrative: During a Heightened Monitoring Inspection, it was found that an incident of three children running away from the operation was not reported to licensing until 9 hours after the incident occured.
Correction Narrative:
I received the following email from the operation on 12/29/2023:

"Corrective Action: The administration will carry out a retraining session on the correct procedure for promptly reporting to licensing when a child has left our facility without permission.

1. Organize a training session on how to handle situations involving a runaway child.
2. Make sure the staff is fully informed about the age restrictions of our youth and the required waiting period before we report a runaway child to licensing.
3. Ensure our staff is aware of when to contact our local authorities in the event of a child running away.

By implementing these steps, we can ensure that our organization is well-structured, organized, and knowledgeable, ensuring us to work cohesively as a team."

Deficiency Narrative: The victim child and several children who witnessed the restraint indicated that the staff used more physical force than required while conducting the restraint.
Correction Narrative:
I, Andrew Ward, received the following email from Eric Harris:

Licensing officials recently investigated at our facility regarding a two-person restraint that was performed on a child. After their thorough examination, it was determined that Adiee Emergency Shelter failed to meet the minimum standard 748.2551 (c) (2) for EBI implementation. Specifically, it was found that caregivers did not use the minimal amount of reasonable and necessary physical force.

To rectify this deficiency and ensure the safety and well-being of all children, RCC will undertake the following corrective actions.


1. Review and Update Policies: We will carefully evaluate our current policies concerning physical force used during child restraints. We will ensure that these policies align with best practices, local laws, and regulations. If necessary, we will make updates to clearly emphasize the importance of minimal force and prioritize the child's safety.

2. Training and Education: Comprehensive training will be provided to all staff members involved in restraining children. This training will cover important topics such as child development, de-escalation techniques, and alternative methods of restraint that do not involve physical force. Staff members will be educated on the potential risks of excessive force and the vital importance of using the least amount of physical force necessary.

3. Clear Guidelines: We will develop clear guidelines and protocols for staff to follow when restraining a child. These guidelines will strongly encourage the use of non-physical techniques whenever possible. They will also outline the specific circumstances in which physical force may be deemed necessary. We will ensure that these guidelines are easily accessible, well-communicated, and regularly reviewed with all staff members.

4. Continuous Supervision: We will implement a system of continuous supervision, where staff members will actively monitor and assess a restrained child's behavior and needs. This proactive approach will allow for early intervention and minimize the need for physical force.

5. Regular Evaluation and Feedback: Conduct regular evaluations of staff performance and provide constructive feedback. Encourage open communication to address any concerns or questions regarding the use of physical force on child restraints. This will help maintain accountability and ensure that staff members are consistently following the established guidelines.

6. Reporting and Documentation: Establish a clear procedure for reporting and documenting instances where physical force is used on a child restraint. This will help identify any patterns or area.

implementing these corrective actions will enhance the safety and well-being of the children under our care. We fully understand the importance of using only the minimal amount of reasonable and necessary physical force. We will do everything in our power to ensure that all children receive the utmost care and protection they deserve.

Deficiency Narrative: There is no medication error protocol or documentation regarding children who have missed a dose of medication.
Correction Narrative: The operation update medication records to include the following documentation: The child's name, prescription number, the prescribing physician, medication name, instructions, date/day of week/month/year, side effects, why the medication is administered, the name and address of the pharmacy, the medication count, whether the child refused or took the medication, and a signature slot for both the child and staff member. The operation also identified key staff to administer medications and retrained those staff.

Deficiency Narrative: Medication logs reviewed did not have an accurate count, in addition the medication that was administered last night was not fully documented as the staff did not sign the log for the 7pm dose on 10/24/23 as required per the minimum standards.
Correction Narrative: A medication error sheet was added to each resident's medication log so that all medication errors can be documented and reported in a timely manner. Medication logs have the resident name, time and date of error, name of medication, type of error, and signature slots for staff and children. The operation also identified key staff to administer medications and retrained those staff.

Deficiency Narrative: Children in care are running out of medication and miss doses of medication until the operation is able to get a refill.
Correction Narrative:
The following email was received from Adiee Emergency Shelter:
We acknowledge the seriousness of this issue and the violation of Minimum Standard 748.2003(b)(3) regarding the administration of prescription medication. We are committed to ensuring the health and well-being of all children in our care and understand the importance of administering medication according to instructions or a prescribing healthcare professionals order.

In response to this, we have implemented a corrective action plan. The LCCA will ensure all children in our care do not miss doses of medication. The following measures have been put in place:

1. The case worker is no longer allowed to leave the resident at the facility without 30 days of medication.
2. Placement agencies have been notified of the final changes to the intake process when placement is occurring with the child.
3. If the child does not have the proper amount of medication, the placement will be denied until the medication is received.

In addition, the medication is currently being counted by the incoming staff with the staff that is present at shift change. We have also requested that placement agencies do not send children to the facility with less than 30 days of medication.

Currently, the medication is correct for all our residents. We believe these measures will ensure that our residents do not miss their medication and that we follow all relevant standards.

During a Heightened Monitoring Inspection conducted 12/11/2023, medications were counted, and documentation was reviewed. The standard was found to be in compliance.

Deficiency Narrative:
During a review conducted on September 25, 2023, it was determined that: 

(1)	your operations administrator failed to ensure compliance with the current HM Plan(s); and 

(2)	12 months had elapsed since the effective date of the plan.

As you know, the heightened monitoring plans for your operation included a specific planned end date at the 12-month mark by which your operation was expected to meet all heightened monitoring criteria necessary to move out of active heightened monitoring to a phase of post plan monitoring.  As a direct result of the administrators failure to ensure timely compliance with heightened monitoring plans, your operation is now unable to successfully move to post-plan monitoring.  Furthermore, your operations planned end date must now be revised, and the period of heightened monitoring must be extended.

Further details of the failure of your operations administrator to ensure compliance include the following: 

-	Your operation received a Medium-High weighted citation in a pattern/trend category on March 31, 2023. Specifically, the operation was cited for 748.3353(c)- Monitoring Devices. The operation met compliance April 13, 2023. 

-	Operation failed to demonstrate 6 months of successive compliance with the standard and contract requirements that led to heightened monitoring; and

-	Operation was unable to meet compliance with Medium-High or High weighted licensing citations. 

Finding: 748.535(2)  The licensed administrator must ensure the operation complies with current heightened monitoring plans.
Correction Narrative: An HM extension was approved effective 9/25/2023.  In conjunction with this extension, a new deadline was established by which all requirements must be completed by your CPA/GRO in order for the operation to be released from its HM plan and move to the Post-plan Monitoring Stage of HM.  Because the extended deadline is now effective, HHSC has determined that the operation is compliant with the requirements of 26 TAC 748.535(2).  The HM deadline for your operation has been extended by 6 months and the new deadline is 3/26/2024.

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation, multiple children were not allowed to back inside the facility following a short period of unauthorized absence.
Correction Narrative: The employee involved in the interaction with the children was terminated immediately (05/08/2023). Going forward all employees will be advised on how to handle situations that prudent judgement is necessary to be used. The administrator ensured all employees were retrained on children's rights on 10/13/2023. Training sign-in sheet revieiwed.

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation it was found that a caregiver failed to exercise prudent judgement in the presence of children when the caregiver failed to actively search for children in the vicinity from which they had gone missing and when the caregiver transported children in the trunk of a vehicle.
Correction Narrative: Employee involved in the interaction with the children was terminated immediately. (05/08/2023). The administrator ensured that all employees were trained on the procedures of how and when to report. A copy of the AWOL policy was attached with this email.

Deficiency Narrative: The operation failed to follow their own policy when they transported children without the use of seatbelts and when they failed to report several children's unauthorized absences from the facility within the timeframes required by their policy.
Correction Narrative: The administrator ensured that Adiee's policy to never transport children without seatbelts was reviewed by staff. All staff members have had a refresher training on Adiee Transportation policy. A copy of the policy and signature seat was reviewed. All vehicles were provided a transportation binder that includes transportation logs, policy, medical information, phone numbers, and the AWOL policy.

Deficiency Narrative: During the investigation it was found that six children and one caregiver went on an outing in a vehicle that had five seatbealts.
Correction Narrative: The Administrator ensured that all staff members are of aware of how to transport children in care, specifically on not exceeding capacity of seatbelts. This review was completed on 10/13/2023.

Deficiency Narrative: A caregiver neglectfully supervised multiple children in care when she transported them in the trunk of a vehicle.

ADIEE will place a plastic covering over the panel to add an extra step of security to protect access to the box. We are open to any further suggestions.
